texts.shortText: Elongate, cylindrical worm strongly tapering at both ends and with particularly narrow tail. The head is very distinctive and consists of a narrow, elongated, annulated cone made up of successively smaller rings and tipped by two pairs of tiny tentacles. When disturbed (or when attacking prey) an enormous cylindrical proboscis is shot out of the mouth and this ends in four formidable, sharply-pointed jaws. The segmental limbs (parapodia) are smallish, but distinct and each has a single tubular gill on its dorsal surface. Body colour transparent white, suffused with pink.
Body length typically about 60 mm, but up to 100 mm.

Global: Widespread across Europe, including Mediterranean, Caribbean, Red Sea and Southern Africa, also across Indo-Pacific.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.

Fairly large, active worm that burrows in sandbanks and feed on benthic invertebrates. Lashes about vigorously when disturbed and may also extend and retract the enormous proboscis. The jaws of glycerids are associated with venom glands and some larger species can inflict painful bites!
Carnivorous, feeding on other worms and smaller crustaceans.
Eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.

The small, elongated, conical head and enormous toothed proboscis and very characteristic making it unlikely that this species would be confused with any other regional polychaete. Along the east coast a second similar species G. subaenea also occurs and this has a tuft of five, rather than one, gill filament dorsally on each lateral limb. There are also several other less common regional species.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 66).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 1 (p. 360).

von Reumont, BM, Campbell, LI, Richter, S, Hering, L, Sykes, D, Hetmank, J., et al. & Bleidorn, C (2014). A polychaeteâ€™s powerful punch: venom gland transcriptomics of Glycera reveals a complex cocktail of toxin homologs. Genome Biology and Evolution, 6(9), 2406-2423.
